texts.en: Jacqueline is a young Cameroonian, 35 years old, unmarried, and the mother of two children, 3 and 10 years old, who are both in school. Jacqueline has had a grocery store in a district in the city for five years in which she sells bread, chocolate, butter, candy, cookies, and also beverages. She would like to use this loan to buy 30 cases to increase her revenues, which will enable her later to meet the educational needs of her children.

loans.use: to buy 30 cases of beverages

loans.name: La Domesticas Group

texts.es:
El grupo las domesticas lo conforman tres mujeres trabajadoras ellas son Julia del Socorro quien elabora cepillos, Margarita quien vende ropa y elabora cepillos y Dolores comerciante de productos AVON.
Julia del Socorro inicio con la elaboración artesanal de cepillos de lavar ropa hace 15 años donde trabaja junto a sus dos hijos y un sobrino quien es el que se encarga de distribuir y vender.  El crédito lo invertirá en materia prima nailon, madera, grapas…etc.
texts.en:
Las Domesticas group is made up of three hardworking women: Julia del Socorro who makes brushes, Margarita who sells clothing, and Dolores who sells Avon products.
 Julia del Socorro started producing handmade brushes to wash clothes 15 years ago.  She works together with her two children and a nephew who is in charge of sales and distribution.  She will use the loan to buy nylon, wood, staples, etc.

loans.use: to buy nylon, wood, staples, etc

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
This is Peter. He received a previous 13,000 PHP loan that he used to purchase scrap materials that he needed in his recycling business. His earnings were a big help for the education of his children and for his family's personal, household, and business expenditures. 

Peter is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan to buy scrap material. The profits from his loan will definitely help to sustain his family's daily needs and educational expenses of his children. Peter looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart. He hopes to be able to expand soon, and he fervently hopes to have his own truck. Peter faithfully meets up weekly with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. Groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy scrap and recycled materials

loans.name: Theogene

texts.en:
Theogene is married and has a five-year-old child. His child has been enrolled in school. Theogene has been a rice grower for 9 years. He has requested a Kiva loan to use for seedling beds and to support labor costs. He plans to use the profits for paying school fees for the child, to provide savings, and to pay for medical insurance.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To prepare seedling beds and to support labor costs.

loans.name: Bomoko 2 Group

texts.en:
Josephine, age 42, is married and has a 20 year-old child. This child is currently attending school. Josephine is representing the Bomoko 2 group. She owns a small grocery shop in Brazzaville. She has been operating this shop for one year. She will use the loan to reinforce her inventory. She will buy items such as flour, sugar, milk, and canned sardines. Her business strategy is to keep a running list of her inventory so that she does not run out of a certain product. She wants to keep her shop fully stocked at all times. 
Josephine has received 4 previous loans from Kiva’s partner, HOPE Congo. She has a good repayment record. She would like to start a business selling children’s clothes. She hopes to travel abroad to China to buy the clothes to sell.

loans.use: to pay for milk, flour, and sugar.

loans.name: Thyhoeurng's Group

texts.en:
Thyhoeurng is a 29-year-old mother of three children: two daughters and one son, all of whom are still dependent on her and are in school.  She has been earning a living through farming rice on one hectare of farmland for four years to support the family.  The current business earns her about KHR 20,000 per day and she manages to save about KHR 10,000 each day after daily expenses.

This is the second microloan for Thyhoeurng’s group of two members with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund who live in the same village of Mongkul Borey district of Banteay Meanchey province.  She completely paid back the loan which has helped improve her family's standard of living.  Now leading her group to request for a new loan with VisionFund, Thyhoeurng will use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland.  She hopes this loan will enable her to earn more income so as to save some money to buy a mini-tractor for use in her field

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Safiya

texts.en:
Safiya is 58 year old.  She is married and has 4 children.  She is a person who always falls in a story.   A month ago she went to her friend's house and saw a big cow which nearly knocked her down with his antlers.  She was frightened and overwhelmed.  Returning to her home she decided to get money from the animal which scared her. 

In this way she is going to begin own business to deal with animal husbandry.  She will be one of the best and successful business women in the local market because she is smart and industrious.  She’ll buy cows and care for them for 2 to 3 month and then sell them to local people.  She is asking for a loan of 1000 TJS to buy cows.  In this way she will provide her family with a higher standard of living.  She promises to make her payment on time.  She awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy cows

loans.name: Jehovah Jireh 2 Group

texts.en:
Arnauline, age 31, is a single mother of a 4 year old child.  Her mother lives with her and Arnauline provides for the family.  She is representing the Jehovah Jireh 2 group. 

Arnauline owns a used clothing stand in a market.  She has owned this small business for 10 years.  She will use the loan to buy large bales of used clothing from her supplier.  In the Congo, used clothing is combined into large bundles, bought my vendors, and then separated out to be sold separately.  Her business strategy is to have regular sales to attract customers to her stand. 

Arnauline has received 4 previous loans from HOPE Congo.  She has a good repayment record.  She hopes to move from her stand into a boutique in the future.

loans.use: to pay for bales of used clothing

loans.name: Pelagie

texts.en:
Pelagie aged 48.  She is married and has seven children between the ages of 10 and 26 years old.  All of her children attend school.  She has been a rice farmer for four years and her husband also works as a farmer.  She has requested a Kiva loan to use to pay for her labor cost.  She plans to use the profits to pay school fees for the children and to pay for medical insurance.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To use the loan to pay for her labor costs.

loans.name: David Orlando

texts.es:
David, está solicitando un nuevo préstamo para la compra de mercadería, pues considera que a través de estos financiamientos la disponibilidad en el negocio ha mejorado, para poder atender la demanda de los clientes, su inversión será en la compra de hierro de varias medidas, lamina y pintura, para continuar fabricando puertas, ventanas de balcon.

Con el préstamo anterior tuvo un efecto positivo ya que le ha permitido hasta el momento mantener su negocio surtido, al mismo tiempo le ha permitido generar para su familia los ingresos necesarios y cubrir todas sus necesidades.
texts.en:
David is applying for a new loan in order to buy merchandise. He believes that thanks to last funding, his business improved and he had more merchandise available to meet his customers demand.  

His investment will be in buying iron of different sizes, plates and paint to keep making doors and balcony windows. The previous loan had a positive effect, allowing him to keep his business well stocked until now. At the same time, it has allowed him to generate enough income to cover all the needs for his family.

loans.use: to buy iron of different sizes, plates and paint

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher is a hardworking married man with three children who lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has been a farmer for the past ten years. Christopher's main business hardships are price fluctuations, seasonal weather, and inadequate capital. He is not able to venture into modern farming. 

Christopher is requesting a loan to pay the workers who are digging his garden. His has a vision of buying more land to grow more crops and expanding his farming activities into new areas. Christopher's personal goals are to educate his children and build a permanent home.

loans.use: to pay the workers who are digging his garden

loans.name: Le Sauveur 1 Group

texts.en:
Marie, who is 60 years old, is married, with five children, ages 22 to 31 years old. She also takes care of her elderly father. 

Marie is representing the Le Sauveur 1 group. She makes and sells beignets in a local market. She has been operating this business for one year. She will use her share of the loan to buy oil, flour, sugar, yeast, and firewood. 

Her business strategy is to give small samples to entice potential customers to buy beignets from her. 

Marie has received three previous loans from Kiva’s partner, HOPE Congo. She has a good repayment record.

loans.use: to pay for oil, flour, sugar, yeast, and firewood.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone!  This is Fatmata from Torkpoi town Bo.  She is 33 years old and married, with two children, 13 years and 17 years.  Her children are currently attending school. 

Fatmata runs a clothing business; she sells wax cotton, lace, and jewelry at home. She has been running this business for 13 years. She works at the business seven days a week, 11 hours a day. Her other source of income comes from her husband's elder brother. 

Fatmata has requested a loan in order to buy more waxed cotton, lace, and jewelry to sell. The extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her living conditions. In the future, she plans to build her own house. 

She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more waxed cotton, lace, and jewelry to sell.

loans.name: Roger

texts.fr: Roger est un homme de 54 ans marié, père de 4 enfants dont l'age varie entre 5et 18 ans, tous vont encore à l'école. Il exerce une activité d'élévage depuis 2 ans déjà (il achète les poussins, les élève ensuite revend) elle fonctionne à merveille mais son capital n'est pas élévé alors, il est obligé à chaque fois d'attendre que le stock acheté pour élever grandisse, qu'il le vende avant de racheter de nouveaux poussins d'où la rupture de stock quotienne qui cause l'insatisfaction de sa clientèle tout le temps. Il sollicite ce crédit pour acheter en grande quantité des poussin et aussi la provende ce qui lui permettra non seulement de satisfaire sa clientèle déjà grandissante mais aussi de réaliser un plus gros profit. Le benéfice que lui apportera ce crédit l'aidera à agrandir son activité( augmenter le nombre de poussins) et aussi à subvenir aux besoins quotidiens de sa famille.
texts.en:
Roger is a 54-year-old man, married, and the father of four children, from 5 to 18 years old, all of whom are still in school. He has been working as a livestock farmer for two years already (he purchases chicks, raises them, and then sells them). Business is booming, but his capital is not great, so he is always compelled to wait for his stock to mature and to sell before buying new chicks, thus causing daily shortages leading to unhappy customers all the time.

He is requesting this loan to buy a large quantity of chicks, and also feed, which will enable him not only to satisfy his already large customer base but also to make a bigger profit. 

The profit that this loan will bring in will help him to expand his business (increase the number of chicks) and also to meet the day-to-day needs of his family.

loans.use: to buy animal feed and chicks

loans.name: Amapolas Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “AMAPOLAS” iniciará el sexto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Los Andes, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Elena es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: tejedora de enaguas, confección de deportivos, tejido de aguayos, tejido de mantas, venta de chocolate, tejido de gorras, tejido de chompas.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Elena es una integrante, ella indica que hace cuatro años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una promotora de la institución que fue a su casa a invitarla. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de tejido de aguayos; cuenta que  desde niña a adquirido este arte, ya que su madre le enseño, con el pasar del tiempo decide volverlo negocio y en la actualidad lo comercializa constantemente.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para la ampliación de su capital (compra de lana) mismo que adquirirá las tiendas distribuidoras y posteriormente lo elaborara y lo comercializará a pedido. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta que le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el crédito y los ahorros.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Amapolas" (Poppies) will begin it's sixth cycle with Pro Mujer as part of Centro Focal de Los Andes.  It is made up of eight members and is led by a board of directors of which Elena is the president.  The businesses that the members of the communal bank carry out are varied, they include: petticoat weaving, sportswear making, aguayo (a type of traditional woolen cloth) weaving, blanket weaving, chocolate sales, hat weaving, and sweater weaving.

The loan that they have taken out will benefit the small micro-businesses where Señora Elena is a member.  She points out that she joined Pro Mujer four years ago, entering upon invitation from a promoter of the institution who came to her house to invite her.  Now she has a business weaving a type of traditional woolen cloth called "aguayo".  She says that she acquired this art as a child because her mother taught her, and that with the passing of time she decided to turn it into a business.  Now she is sells it constantly. 
 
The loan she will now take out is for increasing her capital (buying wool) as well as to acquire shop distributers, and then afterwards make and sell to order.  This form of work allows her to generate resources in order to support her family in every possible way since she is married and has three children.

When she was asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she responded that she likes the loans and the savings.

loans.use: to buy wool.

loans.name: Jecinta

texts.en:
Jecinta is 56 years old. She is married to John and together they have one child. For the past 10 years, Jecinta has been a dairy farmer and she also sells charcoal for additional income.

Jecinta is requesting an 80,000 KES loan. This will be her second loan and she will use the funds to purchase a cow and more stock of charcoal to sell. In the future, Jecinta hopes to start real estate business.

loans.use: to buy a cow and sacks of charcoal to see

loans.name: Le Sauveur 2 Group

texts.en:
Gaudry is 31 years old and single.  He has no children. 

He is representing the Le Sauveur 2 group. Gaudry operates a butcher shop, where he sells fish, beef, and chicken.  He has had this business for one year. He will use the loan to buy fish and other meats to sell in his shop.  His business strategy is to allow his customers to buy meat on credit. 

Gaudry has received three previous loans from Kiva’s partner, HOPE Congo. He has a good repayment record. 

He hopes one day to open a business selling cars.

loans.use: to pay for fish and meat to sell in his shop.

loans.name: Elohim 1 Group

texts.en:
Eugene, age 41, is married with three children, ages 5 to 25 years. He cares for his elderly father as well. 

Eugene is representing the Elohim 1 group. He owns a small pharmacy where he sells different kinds of medicine. He has owned this pharmacy for 19 years! He has learned a lot over the years and can easily hear a customer’s symptoms and advise them on what medicine they should buy.  

He will use the loan to buy more medicine to stock his shelves. His business strategy is to have many different products available to the customers. 

Eugene has received three previous loans from Kiva’s partner HOPE Congo. He has a good repayment record. He would like to expand and open a food market and butcher shop. He hopes to be able to send a child overseas to study.

loans.use: to pay for medicine.

loans.name: Marlene Del Carmen

texts.es:
Marlene, solicita un nuevo préstamo para continuar mejorando el negocio, pues es a través de los fondos prestados que ella considera realizar una buena compra obteniendo los materiales a un mejor precio, por ejemplo el maíz y la leña son aún mejor precio cuando se compran por mayor, tambien comprara aceite, condimentos, quesillo para la elaboracion de pupusas.

Con el préstamo anterior le incrementó la producción en el negocio, tiene un número considerable de clientes para atender, los cuales han permitido generar una mayor ganancia, esta motivada de tener este apoyo para crecer y superarse con su familia.
texts.en: Marlene is requesting a new loan to continue to improve the business, because it is through the borrowed funds that she is expecting to make a big purchase to obtain the supplies at a better price. For example, corn and wood can be obtained at an even better price when they are purchased at wholesale. She will also buy oil, seasonings and cheese to make pupusas (stuffed tortillas). With the previous loan she increased the business' production, and she has a considerable number of customers to service, all of which has allowed her to earn a higher profit. She is motivated because she has this support to grow and better herself together with her family.

loans.use: to buy corn and wood, oil, seasoning and cheese.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is married and has six children between seven and 21 years old. All of his children are enrolled in school.  For over the past 30 years, Emmanuel has been a rice farmer. The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending for agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

Emmanuel is requesting a Kiva loan to use for seedling beds and to support labor costs. He plans to use the profits from his loan to pay school fees for his children, save for the future, and to pay for medical insurance.

loans.use: to use for seedling beds and to support labor costs

loans.name: Neng's Group

texts.en:
Neng is 39 years old and the mother of three children, one daughter and two sons, all of whom are dependent on her and still in school.  She lives in the rural area of the Ponhea krek district of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, 

She and her husband make a living through farming rice on one hectare of farmland and planting cassava on two hectares of farmland.  They supplement the family’s income by selling vegetables, such as cucumbers, cabbages, eggplants, and mandrel. They are able to earn about KHR 60,000 per day to meet the family’s needs from these businesses, which they have been with for several years. The main challenge is lack of capital for the current business. 

Neang’s group consists of two members who live in the same village.  This is the group's first microloan with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. 

Neang, who is the leader, will use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to earn more income, so she can buy a decent motorbike for commuting as well as to help her family’s business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Eugene

texts.en:
Eugene is 49 years old. He is married to a farmer, and they have four children aged between 5 and 15. All of them attend school. He has been a rice farmer for eight years. He has requested a Kiva loan to use for labor costs. He plans to use the profits for paying school fees for the children and to pay for medical insurance.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37 percent of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65 percent of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90 percent of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to use for labor costs.

loans.name: Haitoy

texts.en:
Haitoy is 49 years old and married. She is going to organize a new business by selling cosmetics, necklaces, chaplets, and other things to earn a living. 

She will be one of the best business women because she is very industrious and smart.  She dreams of expending her business and becoming prosperous in the future. 

She needs a loan to buy goods for organizing business, and that’s why she is asking for a loan of 1000 TJS.  She will look for your help. 

Please, help her if it's at all possible.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and other items for starting a new business

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone!  This is 30-year-old Fatmata from Moriba town Southern area in Bo. She is widowed, with two children, ages 3 years and 14 years. Her children are currently attending school. 

Fatmata runs a provisions shop; she sells soft drinks, bread, sugar, biscuits, and mayonnaise. She has been running this business for 10 years. She works at the business 7 days per week, 12 hours a day. Her other source of income comes from her commercial bike. 

Fatmata says her business is going well because she is the only one who has a shop in her area.  

Fatmata has requested a loan in order to buy more soft drinks, bread, sugar, biscuit, and mayonnaise. The extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children and increase her savings. In the future, she plans to expand her business more. 

She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more soft drinks, bread, sugar, biscuits, and mayonnaise to sell.

loans.name: Mylas' Group

texts.en:
Mylas is 38 years old. She is a married mother and blessed with two children, one daughter and one son, both of whom are dependent on her and in school. 

Mylas lives in a village of the Dambae district of Kampong Cham province, where cassava planting on one hectare has been the main source of the family’s income for seven years. She can earn approximately KHR 20,000 per day and save about KHR 10,000 each day, but the lack of capital for supporting her business is the main challenge for her. 

Mylas’ group consists of two members who have been with VisionFund for three cycles. Mylas has successfully used the past loans to better support her family. She is leading her group to request a loan with VisionFund. 

Mylas is going to use her portion to pay for plowing fees and for labor costs. She hopes to improve her family’s living status by earning more income from the current business and keeping the children in school.

loans.use: to pay for plowing fees and labor costs for her farmland.

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 35-year-old Isatu from Kulanda town Southern area in Bo. She is married, with two children, ages 4 years and 13 years.  Her children are currently attending school. She was a student but she dropped out of school after the birth of her first child.

Isatu runs a boutique; she sells bags, shoes, jeans, and blouses. She has been running this business for seven years. She works at the business 6 days per week, 11 hours per day. Her business is the only source of income she has. Her husband is a security guard; his income is not enough to support the home.  Isatu says the main challenge to her business is that during rainy season, business is slow.

Isatu has requested a loan in order to buy more bags, shoes, jeans, and blouses. The extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her standard of living and educate her children. 

In the future, she plans to build a big house. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more bags, shoes, jeans, and blouses to sell.

loans.name: La Foi Group

texts.en:
Germaine, age 47, is a single mother of three children, ages 16 to 27 years old. All of her children are attending school currently. She also cares for her mother. 

Germaine is representing the La Foi group. She owns a clothing boutique, a business she has operated for more than 20 years. She has gained valuable experience and many loyal customers over the years. 

She will use her share of the loan to buy more clothes to stock her boutique. Her business strategy is to hold regular sales to attract customers to her store. 

Germaine has received four previous loans from Kiva's partner, HOPE Congo. She has a good repayment record. She hopes to own a large boutique in Brazzaville one day.

loans.use: to pay for more clothes to stock her boutique.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 52 years old. She is a business lady and a single mother of five children. She has been supplying potatoes for the past 10 years with the monthly income of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES), which she uses to support her family. 

She is applying for her second loan from KADET LTD after repaying the previous loan successfully. Margaret will use the loan to buy more sacks of potatoes for selling. 

With the anticipated profit from the business, she will educate her children. Her hopes and dreams are to build a store for storage of her potatoes and to improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of potatoes for sale.

loans.name: Dieu Est Bon 1 Group

texts.en:
Maurice, age 61, is married, with five children, ages 15 to 31 years old. Currently, he has three children attending school. He also cares for his elderly father. 

Maurice is representing the Dieu Est Bon 1 group. Maurice has been a "taximan" in Brazzaville for 10 years. He will use the loan to clean up and fix up his car. He feels it is important to do regular maintenance on his car. 

Maurice also has a side business selling vegetables in a market. He enjoys doing different things and hopes to continue to grow his vegetable stand into a large operation. 

Maurice has received three previous loans from Kiva's partner, HOPE Congo. He has a good repayment record.

loans.use: to pay to clean up and fix up his car.

loans.name: Kadie

texts.en:
This is 30-year-old Kadie from Kulanda town Southern area in Bo. She is married, with two children, ages 2 months and 10 years. 

Kadie runs a clothing shop where she sells blouse, bags, shoes, and lace.  She began this business to generate income to support her family.

She has been running it for 11 years. She works at the business 7 days per week and 10 hours a day. The famiy also earns income from her husband, who is working as a businessman.   She says the main challenge to her business is competition in the market.

Kadie has requested a loan in order to buy more blouses, bags, shoes, and lace. The extra income from this loan will allow her to start up a savings account and educate her children. 

In the future, she plans to be an international business woman. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy more blouses, bags, shoes, and lace to sell.

loans.name: Dieu Est Bon 2 Group

texts.en:
Roland, age 36, is married with two children, ages 1 and 4 years old. He is representing the Dieu est Bon 2 group. 

Roland owns and operates a restaurant in Brazzaville. He has owned this restaurant for six years. He will use the loan to buy milk, onions, oil, coffee, spaghetti, and sardines. 

Roland's business strategy is to be open every day of the week, and to open very early each day. He tries to open earlier than the other restaurants in his community. 

Roland has received three previous loans from Kiva's partner, HOPE Congo. He has a good repayment record. 

Roland hopes his restaurant will continue to grow into a large establishment.

loans.use: to pay for milk, onions, oil, coffee, spaghetti, and sardines for his restaurant.

loans.name: Kadijatu

texts.en:
Meet 28-year-old Kadijatu from Kulanda town southern area in Bo.  She is married with one child aged five. Her child is currently attending school. In 2003, Kadijatu established her business. She began her business when she lost her father. She had no one take care of her. She was a student at a vocational centre. She works at the business six days per week and nine hours a day. She says that the main challenge for her business is a poor road network.

Kadijatu requires a loan in order to buy more clothing material like lace, blouses, cotton, and jeans. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her standard of living and education. In the future, she plans to import goods from overseas. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more clothing material like lace, blouses, cotton, and jeans.

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en:
Meet 35-year-old Mabel from Kandeh town, Southern area in Bo, Sierra Leone. She is married with three children between the ages of 4 years and 18 years. Two of her children are currently attending school. 

In 2005, Mabel established her food-stand business. She began her business because she wanted to raise income to support her children. She works at the business every day from 7:00 am to 7:30 p.m. She says that the main challenge to her business is that some of the goods spoil along the way before taken to the market.

Mabel requires a loan in order to buy more palm oil, coconut oil and peppers. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to roof her single room and educate her children. In the future, Mabel plans to build a house. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more palm oil, coconut oil and peppers.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is a 28-year-old married business woman with three children living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. She sells fish and also wants to deal in local brooms because of the high demand in the area. She has been in the fish business for three years which she started with her personal savings. Price fluctuations, high taxes, and seasonal weather changes are the challenges she faces.
However, her personal goals are to educate her children and build a residential permanent house, where as her business dream is to diversify her business to crop farming and move the business to a more permanent location.The purpose of the loan is to buy more brooms and fish for sale

loans.use: to buy more locally-made brooms and fish for sale

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
This is 47-year-old Theresa from Kandeh town Southern area in Bo, Sierra Leone. She is married with 5 children between the ages of 8 years and 22 years. Four of her children are currently attending school, one is in a university.  

Theresa runs a wholesales palm oil business. She sells palm oil and has been running this business for 15 years. She works at the business 7 days per week, 13 hours a day. She also earns income from her younger brother. She says that the main challenges for her business are price inflation and the poor road network at the village where she purchases the palm oil.

Theresa has requested a loan in order to buy more plastic cans of palm oil. The extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her standard of living and educate her children. In the future, she plans to expand her business more. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy more plastic cans of palm oil.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick is a 23-year-old man with 2 children living in Kyenjojo-Uganda. He is a maize farmer and has spent seven years in the field. He started by growing maize on one acre but now has more than two acres. He is faced with the problem of price fluctuations and inflation which affects the prices of maize. Patrick has personal goals of educating his children and building a permanent home. He also has a business goal of hiring employees to expand his business. Patrick wants a loan to pay workers who are weeding his maize plantation.

loans.use: to pay workers who are weeding his maize plantation.

loans.name: Ruben

texts.en:
Ruben is still raising cattle and pigs and growing vegetables, like potatoes and cabbage, for sale. Thanks to his agricultural business, Ruben keeps his family well and has also reconstructed and repaired his house. 

Ruben spent his second Kiva loan on fodder for his farm animals. Now, he is asking again for a loan of 900,000 AMD to buy a large lot of fodder for his cows, bulls, calves, pigs and piglets.

loans.use: to buy a large lot of fodder for his cows, bulls, calves, pigs and piglets.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 31-year-old business woman. She is a single mother of three children. She has been selling fruits and vegetables as a greengrocer in an open-air market for the past ten years, with a monthly income of 5,000 KES which she uses to support her family. 

She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD after having been introduced by an existing KADET customer. Elizabeth will use the loan to buy green vegetables and fresh fruits to sell. With the anticipated profit from the business, she will educate her children. 

Her hopes and dreams are to open a retail shop and improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: to buy green vegetables and fresh fruits to sell.

loans.name: Nighat's Group

texts.en:
Mrs Nighat, a 35-year-old woman, is a mother of six children living in one of the poorly developed areas of Rawalpindi, Pakistan. With the meager salary of her husband, she is finding it difficult to run her kitchen and to meet the needs of her children.

She is a member of an 3-person lending group and requested for a loan of RS 15,000 from KIVA partner BRAC Pakistan to invest in the expansion of her husband's automobile workshop, which he has been running for 15 years.  

She is confident that the loan can help the family to increase her husband's income.

loans.use: To expand her husband's  automobile workshop.

loans.name: Evariste

texts.en:
Evariste is 66 years old. He is married to a farmer. They have three children, and all of their children attend school. Evariste has been a rice farmer for eight years. He has requested a Kiva loan to support labor costs. He plans to use the profits to pay school fees for his children and to pay for medical insurance.

The agricultural sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition, because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to support labor costs.

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en: Lawrence is a 61-year-old businessman living Bundibugyo, Uganda. He has a retail shop and has been in business for 12 years. Price fluctuations and inadequate capital to buy stock are the challenges he is facing. His goal is to hire employees to enable him to expand his business into new markets. The purpose of this loan is to buy matchboxes, sugar, beans and rice to sell.

loans.use: to buy matchboxes, sugar ,beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Exode Plus Group

texts.en:
Stephane is the chairman of the Community Bank named “Exode Plus,” which is composed of 18 members united in solidarity for receiving Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.
Stephane has been part of the micro-enterprise world since 2004. He sells slippers. His business is located to the mid-west of Kinshasa. Stephane is happy to be one of HOPE DRC’s clients. He is a trustworthy client, having obtained and correctly repaid three loans. 
The loan he will obtain next will be used to buy pairs of slippers in bulk to resell retail with the goal of increasing his profits. His business generates a profit of US$60 per week. Stephane is 40 years old, married and the father of five children whose ages range between 4 and 13. Four of them go to school.

loans.use: to buy more pairs of slippers to resell at a profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en:
Mathew is 29 years old, married to Caroline and blessed with two children aged eight and four. He sells electronic goods on credit, a business he ventured into three years ago. He earns a monthly income of 20,000 KES. 
Mathew wants to purchase more electronics for sale and has requested a first loan of 30,000 KES. The profit he makes from his business will aid him in educating his children. His dream is to see his business grow bigger and bigger.

loans.use: to purchase more electronic goods for sale.

loans.name: Mamie

texts.en:
This is 35-year-old Mamie from Torkpoi town Southern area in Freetown, Sierra Leone. She is married with two children between the ages of 13 and 17. She has five relatives at home and also seven students who are currently attending school, as well as her immediate family.

Mamie runs a food stand. She sells rice, palm oil, Maggi (seasoning for soups and stews), onions and oil. She has been running this business for 12 years. She works at the business every day, 13 hours a day. Her business is the only source of income she has. She says that the main challenges to her business are transportation costs and the scarcity of palm oil. 

Mamie has requested a loan in order to buy more rice, palm oil, Maggi, onions and oil. The extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children and improve her standard of living. In the future, she hopes to see her business grow. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy more rice, palm oil, Maggi, onions and oil.

loans.name: Gaspard

texts.en:
Gaspard is 49, married to a farmer and has five children, all of whom attend school. He has been a rice farmer for eight years. He has requested a Kiva loan to use to meet labor costs. He plans to use the profits to pay his children's school fees and to pay for medical insurance.
The agriculture sector accounts for 37 per cent of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65 per cent of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90 per cent of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to meet labor costs.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Tiangah

texts.en:
Tiangah is 50 years old and married with four children, ranging in age from 15 to 25. She runs a food stand in a busy market area at Kandeh town Southern area in Bo, Sierra Leone.

She has been in this business for 30 years, selling onions, Maggi (seasoning), pepper and garden egg (eggplant) at her house. Her older children also earn an income. She says her business is going well because the market is very close to her house.

Tiangah requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to buy similar items like onions, Maggi, pepper and garden egg.  She says that the extra income from this loan will help her improve her standard of living. In the future, she would like to expand her business to a shop level. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy items like onions, Maggi, pepper and garden egg to sell

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en: Zaina is a 38-year-old single mother of five children living in Masindi, Uganda. For six years she has been operating a retail shop. She started the business with money she had earned as a market vendor. Price fluctuations and inflation are her major challenges. Her dream is to educate her children up to university and to buy land to grow crops. With this loan, Zaina wants to buy general merchandise, such as soap and sugar, to sell.

loans.use: to buy general merchandise such as soap and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her nursing studies.

loans.name: Safina

texts.en: Safina is a 52-year-old businesswoman living Bundibugyo, Uganda. She deals in cocoa and has been in business for six years. She started with savings from her salary as a bursar in a school. Price fluctuations and the seasonal nature of the crop are her major challenges. Her business goal is to expand her business into new markets. The purpose of this loan is to buy more cocoa to sell.

loans.use: to buy more cocoa to sell

loans.name: 3 De Noviembre   (Portoviejo) Group

texts.es:
En la parroquia Andrés De Vera de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúnen  cada quince días los 2 socios y las 11 socias del Banco Comunal 3 de Noviembre. Se dedican a diversas actividades tales como comercio en general, servicios, entre otras actividades. Este es su segundo ciclo en el banco y están muy contentos porque el crédito anterior que recibieron les ayudo de mucho para sus negocios y su vida diaria.

En este lugar vive la señora Ayda, tiene 41 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene cuatro hijos de 18, 17, 16 y 13 años los mismos que estudian el mayor en universidad y los tres menores en colegio. El marido trabaja en una empresa constructora. 

Nuestra amiga para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y en especial para los gastos de estudios  de sus hijos se dedica a varias actividades, ella labora de empleada domestica en una casa de esta ciudad, pero en sus ratos y días libres se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo y de productos de Esika (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Con esto ella se gana algo extra y así ayuda a sus hijos ya que sus estudios representan grandes gastos y para ella lo más importante es que ellos tengan una muy buena educación. Tiene 3 años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar ropa, perfumes, cremas y cosméticos. Este es el segundo ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que le han dado tanto a ella como a sus compañeros del grupo.
 
Su sueño es que sus hijos sean buenos profesionales.
texts.en:
In the  Andrés De Vera parish of the city of Portoviejo the 11 members of the 3 de Noviembre communal bank meet every two weeks. They work in different activities such as general sales, services and more. This is their second cycle in the bank and they are very happy because the previous loan they received helped them a lot with their businesses and their daily lives.

Ayda lives in this place. She is 41 years old and in a common law marriage from which she has four children aged 18, 17, 16 and 13. The oldest is in college and the three youngest are in high school. Her husband works in a business. 

In order to help her husband with the household expenses, especially her childrens' education expenses, she works doing several things. She works as a domestic employee in a house in town, but in her free time and on her days off she sells all types of clothing and Esika products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes and women's accesories). With this, she earns something extra and this way she helps her children, since their education represents a big expense and for her the most important thing is for them to have a very good education. She has been doing this activity for 3 years and it is going very well for her.

This loan is to buy clothes, perfumes, creams and cosmetics. This is her second cycle in the communal bank and she likes it because they have given her and her group companions so much.

Her dream is for her children to have good professions.

loans.use: to buy clothes, perfumes, creams and cosmetics

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
Nancy tiene 52 años, es una mujer emprendedora y muy trabajadora. No tiene ninguna relación sentimental desde hace muchos años, ya que se ha dedicado a velar por el cuidado de sus cuatro hijos, con quienes vive en la casa que pudo construir durante el tiempo que vivió junto a su ex pareja. 

Nancy es una mujer que disfruta del trabajo, no le gusta estar inactiva es por eso que no desmaya cuanto de realizar alguna labor se trata. Su fuente de ingreso principal consiste en el alquiler de motocarros, tiene tres, de los cuales; uno presenta está en óptimas condiciones, otro que requiere algunos arreglos y el tercero, desde hace 5 años necesita una refacción completa para ponerlo en circulación. Se inició en este negocio hace 8 años y sus ingresos diarios se han incrementado. Con el paso del tiempo ha ido generándose otras fuentes de ingreso económico, es por eso que hace 5 años ha establecido una tienda afuera de su casa donde vende todo tipo de abarrotes, tiene también una refrigeradora para la venta de gelatinas, chupetes y gaseosas. Y por si fuera poco, dedica sus noches a trabajar en la Municipalidad de la ciudad realizando labores de limpieza y acondicionamiento público pasando 8 horas dejando limpias e impecables las calles de la ciudad. Todo lo que realiza le gusta mucho y no duda en poner su mayor esfuerzo para trabajar cada día con mucho optimismo. 

Este es su primer crédito con MFP, agradece la oportunidad y la ayuda que le brindan las personas para acceder a este financiamiento que le ayudará a mejorar su trabajo. Por lo que se compromete a pagar puntualmente todas las cuotas y espera continuar trabajando junto a los integrantes de su banco comunal.
El monto solicitado (1000 nuevos soles) lo invertirá en la compra de llantas y un nuevo motor, refaccionará el sistema de arrastre y pagará la mano de obra del mecánico que reparará su motocarro inactivo.
texts.en:
Nancy is 52 years old. She is an enterprising and very hard-working woman. She has been without a partner for many years since, as she has been busy looking after her four children, with whom she lives in the house which she was able to build whilst living with her ex-partner.

Nancy is a woman who enjoys working. She does not like being inactive and for this reason she does not mind when there is work to do.

Her main source of income is hiring out tricycles. She has three, one in good condition, one which needs some repairs and a third which has been in need of a complete refurbishment for five years. 

She started this business 8 years ago and her daily income has increased. Over time she has generated other sources of income. Five years ago she set up a shop outside her house where she sells all sorts of groceries. She also has a refrigerator from which she sells  jelly, popsicles and soft drinks. And if this were not enough she also works for the municipal council by night cleaning and tidying public spaces and leaving the city streets impeccably clean. She carries out all of this work with great enthusiasm and does not hesitate to put all her effort into working hard each day with much optimism. 

This is her first loan with MFP. She is grateful for the opportunity and the help people are offering her to access this loan which will help her to improve her business. For this reason she promises to make all her repayments punctually and she hopes to continue working together with the members of her communal bank. 

She will  use the loan of 1000 nuevos soles to buy tyres and a new engine, fix the drive system and to pay for the labour costs of the mechanic who will be fixing her inactive tricycle.

loans.use: to buy tyres and a new engine, repair the drive system and pay for he labour costs of the mechanic who will be fixing her inactive tricycle.

loans.name: Mondukpè M. Justine's Group

texts.fr: Il s'agit d'un groupe de deux personnes en caution solidaire. Agée de 34 ans, Mondukpè Justine vit avec son mari et mère de quatre enfants scolarisés. Le plus âgé a 17 ans et le moins âgé a 05 ans. Mondukpè Justine distribue des plastiques, des mèches, des paquets de macaronies et des glacières dans sa localité depuis 03 ans. Elle fait ses achats dans l'un des marchés du Bénin et ses clients augmentent de jour en jour grâce à la bonne la qualité de ses articles. Soucieuse de renforcer son pouvoir d'achat et de satisfaire la demande de ses clients, elle a fait recours au financement de Finadev. L'intérêt tiré de ce financement lui permettra de fournir des soins médicaux adéquats à ses enfants et de participer à leurs scolarisation. Mondukpè Justine la responsable se retrouve à gauche dans la photo.
texts.en:
This is a group composed of two people who are joint guarantors. Mondukpè Justine, who is 34 years old, lives with her husband and is the mother of 4 children who attend school. The eldest child is 17 years old and the youngest 5.

Mondukpè Justine has been distributing plastic items, hair extensions, packets of macaroni and coolers in her village for 3 years. She makes her purchases at one of Benin's markets, and her customer base increases from day to day thanks to the high quality of her products. In order to strengthen her purchasing power and satisfy her customer demand, she has turned to Finadev for financial support. The earnings she makes thanks to this loan will enable her to provide her children with adequate health care and to contribute to their educational expenses.

Mondukpè Justine is the group leader and is on the left of the picture.

loans.use: to buy a dozen coolers and 3 dozen mixed plastic items.

loans.name: Shikana Group

texts.fr:
Dorothee fait partie du groupe Shikana et  habite à Bujumbura. C’est une veuve de 60 ans. Elle a 2 enfants  âgés de 37 à 40 ans.
Elle prend soin de ses 5 petits enfants qui étudient.
Elle fait le commerce de pagnes depuis 20 ans. 
Elle est à son dixième  crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle obtient, elle  va  augmenter son capital et acheter beaucoup de pagnes  à revendre pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, elle voudrait  acheter une moto pour vendre le service de transport par moto. En plus, elle voudrait voir ses petits enfants terminer les études.
texts.en:
Dorothee is a member of the Shikana group and lives in Bujumbura. She is a 60-year-old widow. She has 2 children aged 37 and 40. She takes care of her 5 grandchildren, who are all studying.

Dorothee has been selling pagnes (colourful and decorative West African clothing) for 20 years. This is her 10th loan from Turame. Her Kiva-sponsored credit will increase her capital and enable her to buy a lot of pagnes for resale, so that she can earn more money. In the years ahead, she would like to buy a motorbike and sell motorbike transportation services. She would also like to see her grandchildren finish their studies.

loans.use: to buy a lot of pagnes.

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.fr: Bernadette est une femme agée de 59 ans, célibataire mère de 3 enfants dont l'age varie entre 28 et 42 ans. Elle a un Petit restaurant qu'elle gère depuis un déjà. Elle achète le plus souvant les aliments de son restaurant en détail(riz, huile poisson, viande, arachides et boissons, nécessaire petit déjeuné), elle sollicite ce crédit pour augmenter le stock de ces aliments (en gros)en achetant le riz en sac, les bidons d'huile ainsi que les seaux d'arachide et le nécessaire du petit déjeuné ce qui lui permettra non seulement de satisfaire sa clientèle déjà grandissante, mais aussi de réaliser un bénéfice plus élévé qui l'aidera à subvenir à certains besoins quotidiens, aussi d’améliorer le cadre de son activité, de l'agrandir avec le temps en réinvestissant le reste dans son activté.
texts.en: Bernadette is a 59-year-old woman who is single and the mother of 3 children, aged between 28 and 42. She owns a small restaurant which she has been running for a year already. She frequently buys the ingredients she needs to make meals in her restaurant (rice, oil, fish, meat, groudnuts, drinks and the ingredients needed to make breakfast) retail, and she is requesting this loan so that she can increase her inventory of ingredients by buying them wholesale (bags of rice, cans of oil, buckets of groundnuts, and the ingredients needed to make breakfast). This will not only enable her to satisfy her growing clientèle, it will also enable her to earn an increased profit which will allow her to meet certain of her daily needs and to improve the framework for her business; to expand it over time by reinvesting the rest of her earnings into it.

loans.use: to buy the ingredients needed to make breakfast and lunch, wholesale.

loans.name: Chrispinus

texts.en:
Chrispinus, 40 years old and married to Christine, is blessed with six children. A mechanic for 18 years, he currently earns a monthly income of KES 30,000.

Chrispinus has requested his third loan for KES 80,000 to purchase motor vehicle spare parts. The profit he makes will help him educate his children as he dreams and hopes to one day own a garage of his own and be an employer.

loans.use: to purchase motor vehicle spare parts.

loans.name: Lauli

texts.en:
Lauli is a 49-year-old, hardworking, married man who lives in Kagadi, Uganda. He owns a butcher shop that he has run for the past 20 years. He started with agriculture, from which he saved money to start his current business. 

Lauli says price fluctuations and inflation are challenges that affect his business. Lauli would like to educate his children and expand his business to new markets. Lauli would like a loan so he can buy cattle to sell as meat in his butcher shop.

loans.use: to buy cattle to sell as meat in his butcher shop.

loans.name: Went Plus Group

texts.en:
Went Plus is a Community Bank made up of 16 members whose chairwoman is José. These members are united in the same goal: to grow their businesses through loans received from Kiva through the microfinance institution HOPE RDC. 

José is 44 years old, married and the mother of three children, aged between three and ten years old. Two of them attend school. José has been selling fresh foods such as fish and vegetables since 1995. Through hard work and good management, she has succeeded in making her business thrive thanks to the profits she has made. José is a trustworthy client of HOPE RDC, having already obtained and repaid five loans. She will increase her stock of merchandise with her next loan by buying ten boxes of fresh foods and reselling them in her community. Her business generates a profit of US$50 per week.

loans.use: to purchase 10 boxes of fresh food that she can sell at a profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Kholik

texts.en:
Kholik is 45 years old and a hardworking man with a great desire to get ahead. His wife, Shahlo, and he have five children and love them very much. Their ages range from seven to twenty years old. The family lives together in a big house.

Kholik grows a variety of vegetables such as carrots, onions and maize. He began work as a farmer over seven years ago because he needed to earn money. He sells his harvest in the local market and has a lot of customers. His elder daughter helps him with business.  

Kholik is applying for a 2,200 USD loan from IMON to buy seed, fertilizers and fuel for his farm machinery. He would be grateful for your assistance and hopes for your support.

loans.use: to buy seed, fertilizers and fuel for his farm machinery.

loans.name: Sharifaly

texts.en:
Sharifaly as a married parent of 4 children and works hard to support his family. He has a successful business venture. He has had this business for 14 years and earns income from clothes sales. 

He hopes that his hard work will help him attain his dream of saving enough money. In the future, Sharifaly hopes to improve his business in order to provide for the education of his children. He is asking for a loan of 1,100 USD to buy men’s clothes for the new season.
Sharifaly is deeply grateful to KIVA lenders. In this way, his house will be safer and his standard of living will improve, so that he will continue working and fighting to make his biggest dream come true:  ‘TO BE A RICH BUSINESSMAN’.

loans.use: To buy men’s clothes for the new season

loans.name: Venerande

texts.en:
Venerande is 53 years old. She is married and has five children between 14 and 30 years old. All of her children attend school. She has been a rice farmer for eight years and her husband works as a farmer. She has requested a Kiva loan to use to pay for labor costs. She plans to use the profits to pay her children's school fees and to buy medical insurance.
 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37 percent of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65 percent of Rwanda's export revenue and employs approximately 90 percent of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Rosine

texts.en:
Rosine is 38 years old. She is married and has four children between 6 and 15 years old. All of her children attend school. She has been a rice farmer for eight years and her husband works as a farmer. She has requested a Kiva loan to use to pay labor costs. She plans to use the profits to pay for her children's school fees.
 
The agriculture sector accounts for 37 percent of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65 percent of Rwanda's export revenue and employs approximately 90 percent of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Epiphanie

texts.en:
Epiphanie is age 40. She is married and has eight children, between 6 and 18 years old. They all attend school. She has been a rice farmer for eight years and her husband works as a farmer. She has requested a Kiva loan to use to pay her labor costs. She plans to use the profits to pay the school fees for her children and to buy medical insurance.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37 percent of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65 percent of Rwanda's export revenue and employs approximately 90 percent of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a 28-year-old businessman. He is single but he supports his parents. He has been selling shoes for the past six years with a monthly income of KES 10,000, which he uses to support his parents. 

Charles is applying for his first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced by a staff member. Charles will use the loan to buy more stock of shoes. 

With the anticipated profits from sales, he will boost his business. His hopes and dreams are to expand his business and educate his siblings.

loans.use: to buy more stock of shoes to sell.

loans.name: Gideon

texts.en:
Gideon is 39 years old and married to Benedetta. They are blessed with three children, age 12, 8 and 2 years. His wife sells vegetables as an additional income. 

Gideon sells clothes. He has been in this business for four years and earns a monthly income of KES 80,000.

He has applied for his first loan from KADET Ltd., which he will use to purchase more stock of new clothes for sale.

The profit he earns will help him educate his children and expand his business. His dream is to have a better future for his family.

loans.use: to buy more stock of new clothes and shoes for sale.

loans.name: Gedeon Plus Group

texts.en:
Ida, aged 49, is is married and has five children who are between 11 and 25 years old. Three of them go to school.

She is the chairwoman of the Community Bank “Gedeon Plus,” which is composed of 15 members united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through the MFI HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Ida started her business in 2003. She sells Forever personal care products in her environment, located mid-west of the city of Kinshasa. Each week, her business brings in a profit of about US $40. 

She is a loyal client of the MFI HOPE RDC who has already received nine different loans and has repaid them properly. As the Forever product demand is high in her community, she intends to use the next loan to increase her stock of merchandise and resell it with the aim of increasing her profits. 

Her ambition is to open a drugstore.

loans.use: to increase her stock of forever products.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Progression Plus Group

texts.en:
Progression Plus is a community bank made up of 13 members whose chairwoman is Petronie. These members are united for the same goal: to grow their businesses using loans received from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC.

Petronie is married and has four children who are between 18 and 25 years old. Three of them attend school.

She sells palm oil in a market located to the west of Kinshasa. She has been in business since 2000. Her beginning business capital was US $20. With hard work and good management, Petronie’s business has prospered and generates a profit of US $60 per week. 

She has already borrowed nine loans from the MFI HOPE DRC for business expansion and fully repaid them. Petronie intends with the next loan to purchase 400 litres of palm oil for resale in order to meet her clients’ needs and generate additional profits.

loans.use: to buy 400 litres of palm oil for resale at a profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Selly

texts.en:
Selly is 44 years old and single. She has four children between 17 and 3 years old.

She has been in a second-hand clothing business for the past 10 years, earning KES 5,000 monthly.

This is her first loan of KES 10,000 from KADET Ltd. She will use the loan to purchase bales of second-hand clothes for resale.

With the anticipated profits, she plans to open a saloon. Her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase bales of second-hand clothing for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy clothes, handbags, hair products and equipment for the business.

loans.name: Nzapa Nzoni Plus Group

texts.en:
Martin is a leader of a Community bank named “Nzana Nzoni Plus,” which is composed of 11 microentrepreneurs united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Martin 47, is married and sells Forever personal care products. He has been in business for years. He is working hard because his ambition is to become a Forever products provider in his area. As he wants to develop and diversify his business, he decided to join one of Hope’s groups in January 2009. 

He is planning with the next loan to increase his Forever product stock to resell in order to increase his working capital. He makes a profit of about US $150 per week. 

Martin has succeeded with good strategies to build up permanent customers. He always talks with his customers, he knows them well by their names, and he never runs out of stock.

loans.use: to increase his stock of forever products.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en:
Teresia is a hardworking business lady and a single mother of one child. She operates a hardware store in a conducive environment with reliable customers to earn a living. She has been in the business for one year. 

Through the seminars she attended in Faulu Kenya, she has become economically empowered. She dreams of expanding her business in the future. She needs a loan of 100,000 KES to buy water pumps for resale.

loans.use: To buy water pumps for resale.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 35 years old, married to Michael and blessed with five children age 16, 13, 10, 7 and 3 years old. She sells second-hand clothes alongside farming. 

She started this business 12 years ago and earns a monthly income of KES 20,000. She has requested a first loan of KES 15,000 to purchase two bales of jackets to sell. 

The profit she earns from this business will help her pay school fees for her children as well as add more stock. Her dream is to one day open up a wholesale shop for this type of business.

loans.use: To purchase two bales of jackets for sale.

loans.name: Retoños Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “RETOÑOS” iniciará el segundo ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Collpani, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Santusa es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: Producción de enaguas y mantillas, costura de polleras, repostería, tejido de mantas, elaboración de colchones, carpintería, venta de comida.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Santusa es una integrante, ella indica que desde hace tres ciclos que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una promotora de la institución que fue a su casa a invitarla. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de elaboración de enaguas bordadas; da a conocer que  este negocio lo aprendió de su familia desde hace tiempo atrás, pero ella decidió emprender un negocio sola.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para ampliar el negocio (compra de telas) mismo que comprará de las ferias de la Ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará en las ferias de las fronteras bolivianas - peruanas. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene cinco hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta que le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones en crédito y salud.
texts.en:
The Retoños communal bank will start its second cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Collpani Focal Center.  It is comprised of eight members, and it is led by a governing board.  Santusa is the president.  The businesses that the members of the communal bank carry out are varied.  Among them are the production of petticoats and veils, making traditional skirts, making pastries, weaving blankets, making mattresses, carpentry, and selling food.

The loan that they will take out will benefit the group’s  small businesswomen, where Santusa is a member.  She joined Pro Mujer three cycles ago.  She joined on invitation from one of the institution's promotors who came to her house to invite her.  She currently has a business of making embroidered petticoats.  She says that she learned this business from her family some years ago.  However, she decided to undertake a business by herself.

The loan that she will now take out is to expand her business (to buy fabric).  She will buy the fabric at the fairs in the city of El Alto.  She will later sell what she makes at the fairs on the Bolivian – Peruvian border.  This way of working allows her to generate resources to support her family as much as she can.  She is married and has five children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she said she likes the trainings about loans and health.

loans.use: to buy fabric.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles lives in the Nanyuki area of Central province, Kenya. He is married and has six children. 

He owns a tee tree farm for commercial purposes, from which he sells oil extracted from the tree leaves. He has operated the business for two years now. Charles has previously been farming; keeping cattle, planting maize, beans and potatoes.

Charles learnt about Milango through a friend with an aim of accessing credit to improve on the operation of the business. The challenge he faces is lack of money.

Charles is applying for a loan of 10,551 Kenya shillings, which he will use to purchase tea tree seedlings for the farm. The extra income from the loan will be added to the savings to purchase more tea tree seedlings.

loans.use: To purchase tea tree seedlings for the farm.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice lives in the Nanyuki area of Central province, Kenya. She is married and has four children. 

She owns a tea tree farming business and also plants food crops for subsistence. The tea tree is used to extract oil for cosmetic purposes.

Alice learnt about Milango through an employee who invited her to the group, and she joined the group with an aim of accessing credit to better her business operations. The main challenges she faces are theft, taxes and seasonal weather.

Alice is applying for a loan of 10,440 Kenya shillings to buy tea tree seedlings for the business. Her extra income from the loan will be added to the savings to purchase more tea tree seedlings. Her ambition is to own dairy cows in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more tea tree seedlings.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 33 years old, married, and has one child. She owns a general store, which she has been running for eight years.  She earns 20,000 KES.

Sarah is requesting her second loan from KADET LTD for 75,000 KES, which she will use to buy sugar, tea leaves, maize flour, cooking oil, and other items.  She will use the anticipated profit to diversify the business and pay school fees for her child. She hopes to own a wholesale shop and open branches within and outside Malaa.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, soap, salt, cooking oil, and maize flour.

loans.name: Shadi

texts.en: Shadi is a 26-year-old young man. He is married and a father to one daughter. He is employed and earns a small salary that is not enough to cover the family's needs. Shadi also is a university student who wants to complete his studies, so he is requesting a loan from FATEN to help him cover the cost of purchasing a new laptop. This will help Shadi to do his homework and reports and help him in his studies. This will ensure a better future for Shadi and improve the family's living conditions. Shadi is photographed at the university where he studies.

loans.use: To purchase a new laptop for educational use

loans.name: Ringera

texts.en:
Ringera lives in Nanyuki, Kenya. He is married and has six children. He owns a tea tree farm, which he has been operating for one year.  Ringera also farms maize, beans, and potatoes on a small scale.

Ringera is requesting a loan for 22,022 KES, which he will use to buy tea tree seedlings. His extra income will be added to his savings to purchase more tea tree seedlings. 

Ringera learned about Milango through a friend who invited him to the group and he joined with an aim of accessing credit to improve his business operations. His main challenges are price fluctuation, inflation, finding customers, and seasonal weather.  He desires that his children own individual businesses in the future.

loans.use: top urchase tea tree seedlings.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, who lives in the Changamwe area of Coast province, Kenya, is married and has two children, neither of whom attends school. He owns a retail shop that sells cooking utensils, basins etc., a business he has been operating for five years now. The challenge he currently faces is finding customers.

Having learned about Milango through a friend, John would like to venture into the transport industry and so is requesting a loan of 73,100 Kenya shillings to buy a motorbike. The extra income arising from the loan will be added to savings to improve his family's living standard. John's future plan is to expand his shop into a wholesale business.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Marisol

texts.es:
La socia  es la señora  Marisol, ella pertenece al banco comunal “Los Hijos de Qolquewasi” de la ciudad del Cusco – Perú. Nuestra socia  se sigue dedicando a la venta de lencería para damas de forma directa,  Marisol trabaja en este comercio hace algún tiempo y es con esta actividad que mantiene a su menor y única hija. La socia en esta oportunidad invertirá su préstamo para capitalizar su actividad y comprará mercadería para cumplir con las solicitudes de su numerosa clientela, la mayoría de ella son mujeres.
Marisol quiere seguir trabajando duro para eventualmente poner una tienda de ropa y lencería y de esa manera procurar darle una mejor educación a su hija.
Marisol está muy agradecida con KIVA por permitirle educar a su hija y por mantenerse y desarrollarse con su actividad.
texts.en:
Marisol belongs to the Los Hijos de Qolquewasi communal bank in the city of Cusco, Peru.  She continues with her direct sales of women’s lingerie.  Marisol has worked in this business for some time.  It is through this business activity that she supports her only daughter, who is a minor.

This time she will use her loan to capitalize her business activity.  She will buy lingerie to fill orders from numerous customers.  Most of them are women.

Marisol wants to continue working hard in order to eventually set up a clothing and lingerie store.  This way she will strive to give her daughter a better education.

Marisol is very grateful to Kiva for allowing her to educate her daughter and maintain and develop her business activity.

loans.use: to buy women's lingerie.

loans.name: Crispulo

texts.es:
Críspulo tiene 52 años, es un hombre muy trabajador y solidario. Con su pareja tiene cuatro hijos, tres de ellos ya son mayores, mientras que el último vive a su lado en su casa propia, la cual lograron construir con el fruto de su trabajo. 

Su trabajo consiste en la siembra y cosecha de palma aceitera, tiene una chacra propia que está a unos kilómetros de su casa. Lleva trabajando en esta actividad por 10 años y lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que le permite aplicar los conocimientos que ha aprendido por largos años en la chacra de sus amigos, siente que es su forma de vida. Le está yendo muy bien, ya que vende su producto a las industrias de su localidad. Su deseo es establecer su propia planta procesadora de la palma para que él mismo pueda establecer su marca y desarrollar su empresa de aceites.

Este es su primer crédito con MFP y está muy contento de saber que tiene un apoyo financiero, ya que así se sentirá más seguro de avanzar con su trabajo. Asimismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago puntual de sus cuotas.
Con el monto solicitado (S/. 500) comprará herramientas (machetes, rastrillos y azadones) que necesita para el mantenimiento de su parcela.
texts.en:
Críspulo is 52 years old. He is a very hardworking and solidary. With his partner, he has four children. Three of them are already adults but the last one lives with them in their house. They were able to build this house as a result of his work. 

His work consists in seeding and harvesting palm oil. He has his own small farm that is situated a couple of kilometers from his house. He has been working in this business for 10 years. What he likes about his work it that it allows him to apply the knowledge he has gained in the course of many years on the farms of his friends. He feels that this is his form of life. It is going very well for him because he is selling his products to local businesses. His wish is to set up his own processing plant so that he can found his own make and develop his oil business.
